p: In practical applications, one would in principle need to know the parameters, both for the SIR model and to calculate the cost [ 4]. For e.g. sexually transmitted diseases, this is not impossible. If one, would base a pilot HIV pre-exposure prophylaxis campaign on mapping a sexual network like Ref. [ 28] (which, in addition to the network itself, could give the contact rates), then one could assume a per-contact transmission probability of 1â€“2% [ 40]. Furthermore, the societal cost for a positive HIV case is well understood [ 41]. With these parameters at hand, it should be possible to narrow down the protocols to one or two.
